column4: i have a quick question for anyone: i am soon likely to own a PC (as opposd to my macs) that will basically be for tinkering. ill want to boot unbuntu, win2000/xp?, and possibly mac osX86. how hard is it to make a machine dual/triple boot between these things? anyone know or have a link to a place that is fairly detailed?
it's easy with Ubuntu. Install Windows first, then Ubuntu.
The Ubuntu installer will detect Windows and configure grub to dual-boot. No idea about OSX.
kbuntu breezy, WinXP.
yes, Kubuntu is KDE on Ubuntu. With gnome-support, though. :-)
Gnome is C based, KDE is C++
KDE is more easily used by someone from Windows.  GNOME is more limited in configuration.
Try both and see which one you like.
install Ubuntu, which will give you GNOME by default. Then use Synaptic to install the kde-desktop package.
Then you'll have both GNOME and KDE installed.  At the login screen, you can choose which one to run.
before installing the kde-desktop package, edit the file "/etc/apt/source.list" and put this line in "deb http://kubuntu.org/packages/kde35 breezy main". Then you'll get the latest & greated KDE.
You don't absolutely need to use the command line. But that's where the power is. :-)
And if you really want to understand Linux (rather than the GUI), you'll do it from the command line.
For what purposes do you use a computer?
You'll use the GIMP then. :-)
Which is available in Windows.
Ubuntu will make it easy for you to use Linux.  But you'll only understand Linux by working at the command line.
then runlevel 1 is your friend. :-)
It will be for a while.

runlevels are the system configurations that Linux can load on booting. In Debian-based distributions (which Ubuntu is), runlevel 1 is the maintenance configuration (i.e. no GUI) and runlevel 2 is the normal operating configuration (i.e. the full GUI environment).
Have fun. :-)
